questions.neutral: Do the streets feel heavier today?

hobby.message: The Council would flinch at your political literature stash.
Urban exploration ever get boring for you?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Heavier, yes. Streets aren’t what they were.
Don’t get out much now, honestly.
I keep busy with old machines, typewriters mostly.
Power cuts made repairs tricky last night.
Some weight in the air, you could say.
Most just stay quiet and out of view.
I keep to my corner, restore typewriters—helps pass the hours.
Lost a ribbon to the last outage.
Hard to find replacements with so many new restrictions.
There's a strange tension, quieter but thicker.
I've always fixed up antique typewriters, just something steady to do.
Power interruptions threw off my usual repair routine yesterday.
Keys jammed twice from dust—older models hate this weather.
Had to finish writing by candlelight; not ideal for ribbon work.
Feels like the old rhythms are missing out there.
Yes, it's heavy. Feels like curfew rules are dissolving in slow motion.
I spend my evenings restoring vintage typewriters—mechanical, not digital, if you can believe it.
Last week, the system glitched and the chimes never sounded.
That silence reminded me why I write by hand—keeps my mind steady when everything else shifts.
Neighbors were noisy for once, ignoring quota reminders, sounded almost... free.
Couldn't concentrate, but I kept typing until the lights flickered out.
I always keep a spare ribbon hidden, just in case.
Definitely heavier, but familiar after all these years.
You know, before retirement, council memos ran through my hands. Now, just old typewriters and journals.
Restoring them is slow work, but honest. Not much use for efficiency at my age.
Last Tuesday, the BCI missed the curfew alert entirely—first time I can recall.
The building was almost lively—neighbors gathering, hardly a glance at the old monitors.
I kept typing anyway, every keystroke louder than usual, no system to measure it.
Funny, I save the best ribbons for nights like that, just in case they vanish altogether.
Feels like the city's clock is broken, and all that's left is the sound of words on paper.
hobby_answer: Yes, still in one piece. Surviving, like the rest of us.
Parts harder to find lately, but I manage.
Curfew chimes missed last week. Slightly easier to work nights.
Don’t take them out much. Safer in the flat.
Small pleasures, in times like this.
Holding up. Keeping me busier than the system prefers, I think.
With the labor mix-up, fewer checks on collectors—at least for now.
People forget typewriters aren't just antiques. They remember everything you type.
System glitches let me work during curfew, less interference.
Still, new quotas worry me. Even hobbies draw attention.
Never know who pays close attention in these places.
Typewriters are running well. A bit of a guilty pleasure these days.
Sourcing ribbons is tricky, especially after the latest distribution mess.
Funny, power disruptions actually help—no BCI eyes, just me and the keys.
Neighbors ignore the schedules lately. Easier to restore machines at odd hours.
I keep my notes off the networks, old habit.
After curfew failures, even restoration feels illicit. Strange times.
It’s almost peaceful, until the lights snap back on.
They're holding up better than most of us, to be honest.
I restored a Royal last night during the blackout—nobody from compliance patrol noticed.
Curfew signals are unreliable now. I type my notes after hours, undisturbed.
Saw neighbors swapping parts in the stairwell—never used to risk that.
Network errors make it easier to get away with old habits.
Strange, but walking down for ink felt less risky this week.
Council’s so focused elsewhere, nobody cares how I spend my evening.
There’s comfort in words the system can’t read.
Holding up, yes, thanks. Honestly, better than I expected in this climate.
Been repairing a 1930s Remington—found it after Halden vanished, believe it or not.
When the labor assignments broke down, half my neighbors forgot quotas altogether.
Restoring by candlelight this week—BCI curfew went silent, nobody watching the time.
I started journaling again in full sentences, not codes or fragments.
Was nearly caught years back for keeping hard copies. Now? Compliance can’t keep up.
It’s risky, but the unpredictability adds a thrill I never felt before.
Some say we’re living through an old story. I write it every night, in my own words.
Strange, but these blackouts and system lapses give space for old ways to breathe.
